conclusion: Determine the velocity v of the conductor rod MN when moving at constant speed considering forces and induced EMFs.
The rod MN moves through a magnetic field B with a velocity v.
The length of the rod in the magnetic field is l.
The induced EMF in the rod is given by E = B * l * v.
The resistance per unit length of the rod is r.
The total resistance R of the rod is r * l.
Using Ohm's Law, the current I induced in the rod is I = (B * l * v) / (r * l) = B * v / r.
The magnetic force FB on the rod is FB = B * I * l = (B^2 * l * v) / r.
The rod is moving at constant speed, so the gravitational force Fg is balanced by the magnetic force FB.
The gravitational force is Fg = m * g.
Set the gravitational force equal to the magnetic force: m * g = (B^2 * l * v) / r.
Rearrange the equation to solve for v: v = (m * g * r) / (B^2 * l).
The velocity v of the conductor rod MN when it is moving at a constant speed is v = (m * g * r) / (B^2 * l).
